title: How many new jobs will the US economy create in January 2016?
preds: Economists polled by MarketWatch predict the number of new jobs created in January 2016 will fall below 200,000 after a large 292,000 gain in December.

After evaluating the impacts/relationships that GDP, SP500 index, credit markets (loans to businesses), and weather have with job growth, I found that not enough evidence exists to adjust my forecast for these parameters.  However, I re-evaluated my multiple autoregressive models and realized my original forecast was not accurately aggregating the prediction intervals.  My aggregated models are predicting a mean job growth of 231; however, the confidence intervals are quite wide.  The small (12%) forecast for the middle bracket (175K-225K) is a result of the small and constrained size of that bracket compared to the bookend brackets.
Because the US is already in a recession.

292K jobs were added in December 2015 (strong in construction and healthcare) but January is traditionally a slower month. 257K were added in January 2015. Reports and projections show that unemployment rate remains steady at 5% yet markets have been jittery thru January.  I'm going to bet on December's surge continuing and jobs added to come at just above 225K.

Building on Okun's Law, I have run a regression with monthly GDP growth and put in an estimation for January 2016 GDP growth. I have looked at the relationship between December and January in terms of job growth for the past ten years and the past 5 years. I have compared job growth in January to average job growth throughout the previous year, and each suggest that job growth in January 2016 will be between 212,000 jobs and 256,000 jobs. More techniques suggest above 250,000 jobs, so I gave it a higher probability.

Screwed up the numbers with my last prediction. The average job growth over the last 6 months has been 228k. If we assume the growth is normally distributed around the mean (It isn't, but nonetheless), we get a standard deviation of about 63. This gives a 48% chance of it being below 225k, with a 20% chance of being below 175.  This isn't exactly high quality econometrics, but whatever. It's better than going by gut instinct.

Based on a crappy statistical analysis I did, which found mean job growth over the last 6 months to be 269.5k. Falsely assuming the data are normally distributed, I estimated a standard deviation of ~65k, which makes getting less than 175k about 6% while the 175-225 range is about 19%. I then scaled up all those probabilities because of general doubt about my modelling (i.e job growth obviously isn't normally distributed). This isn't exactly quality econometrics, but it's reasonable for 15 minutes with a spreadsheet I think. EDIT: Botched the numbers.

- Using employment data (http://www.bls.gov/eag/eag.us.htm) I calculated how often the January employment growth in the last three years fitted within the three groups of <175k, 175-225k, and >225k. This gave a probability of 50%, 20% and 30% respectively
- The next step I took was to look at how employment growth % in January followed the previous quarter (average of Oct, Nov and Dec) in the previous 10 years. Then, using the 2015 Q4 employment data, I used the % growth for each year to calculate how many more jobs would have been created in January. This provides a probability of 60%, 10%, and 30% for each group
- Given that this data includes a number of months where growth was negative, I then analyse the likelihood of negative growth occurring in January, as the recessionary years have a large impact on the overall probability
- Initial jobless claims rose in the week ended Jan 9 by 7,000 (http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-01-14/initial-jobless-claims-in-u-s-unexpectedly-increased-last-week)
- The increase in interest rates may cause a slowdown in employment, but I would expect the results of this to lag a number of months as the effects on investment and recruitment feed through (I also expect the result to be mild)
- Employment is also at it's highest in the last 10 years, and given the slow level of growth in the economy, some doubt whether further growth in jobs is sustainable given the rapid job growth in 2015
- The likelihood of a recession in January is low, given that we are already two-thirds of the way through the month. Assuming that the economy returns to a recession on average once every 6 years, this gives a probability of 17% that a recession will occur in any given year. Citi (http://uk.businessinsider.com/r-watch-for-us-recession-zero-interest-rates-in-china-next-year-citi-says-2015-12?r=US&IR=T) predict a probability of 65% of a recession in 2016, although my expectation is that this is punchy given the fed's optimism about the economy. I would still expect the probability in 2016 to be greater than 17%, so lets meet in the middle at 41%. By pro-rating

The article cited by @Edwinian argues that [slightly] weaker "core retail sales correspond most closely with the consumer spending component of gross domestic product." It is consumer spending that many economists argue to be the leading indicator of job growth. I'm not sure if the coupling is so tight as to be month CS significantly influences subsequent month JG, but maybe it is. @Flyn1200 provides an interesting analysis which correlates monthly S&P 500 directional change with monthly job growth directional change. So, from what I can gather, that makes three negative signals, one of which assumes job growth is a lagging indicator (weaker December consumer spending), and two which assume some concurrency (estimated lower monthly S&P 500 closing and slightly increasing unemployment claims). Oh yeah, plus a nasty weather forecast for portions of the country. Does anybody have any positive signals?

COMMENT:  This article attempts to explain why employment and auto sales  are phenomenal  and the Fed is confident, while the stock market is headed south, GDP growth is about 1% and China seems to be in a nose-dive; why there's bidding wars for some sought-after hires in software and technology even as corporate giants like DuPont, BP and Morgan Stanley plan to lay off tens of thousands; and why the proportion of Americans in the labor force is the lowest since the 1970s, and wage gains for most workers in the recovery have been scant. http://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/18/business/economy/us-growth-and-employment-data-tell-different-stories.html?_r=0 "The explanation for this dissonance may lie at least in part in the changing nature of the American economy.  Indeed, a crucial cause of the split is that the sectors that have been hardest hit — manufacturing and energy production — nowadays count for much less in terms of employment than they do in output. "The nation’s vast array of service industries, which are more labor-intensive, are actually doing far better, . . . .  And the thriving, domestically driven sectors like restaurants, health care, and professional and business services are serving as a firewall protecting the American economy from growing turbulence overseas. "Last year, employment in services, which account for 86 percent of the American work force, jumped by more than 2.3 million, according to Bureau of Labor Statistics data. Manufacturing, which accounts for a mere 9 percent of employment these days, experienced an increase of just 13,000 jobs. "Given the recent numbers for hiring, said Michael Gapen of Barclays, the job market appears to be fundamentally sound. For those seeking to discern the future direction of the economy, he added, “labor markets have sent the better signal.” "And according to those in a position to know, like Tom Gimbel, a Chicago recruiter, demand for new workers remains brisk.“I’ve got more open job orders than I’ve had in a long, long time,” Mr. Gimbel said. His staffing company, LaSalle Network, places workers ranging from operators in call centers who hold just a high school diploma to specialists like accountants and engineers with salaries in the six figures. Small to medium companies, in particular, are providing the growth. “It’s a tale of two cities.  With big companies being more cautious, there’s an opportunity for smaller firms to hire and take market share.”
. . . 
"Overall growth last year was dragged down by weakness in trade and the factory sector, reflecting the sting of the strong dollar on exporters and softness in key markets like Europe and China . . . . "The plunge in oil prices, meanwhile, has meant a reduction in drilling activity and capital expenditures by energy companies . . . . further crimping output as measured by G.D.P.  . . . 
. . . 
“People commonly use employment as a leading indicator,” said David A. Levy, a veteran independent economist in Mount Kisco, N.Y., “but it’s a lagging indicator.”  Mr. Levy said the optimists were underestimating just how big the impact from weakness overseas will be.
“The U.S. economy is going to be pulled into a recession for the first time since World War II by overseas events,” he said. “Emerging markets, including China, are this cycle’s housing bubble.”

Initial prediction is based on a simple time series regression model using the past 3-6 months numbers as a guide. This gives me a forecast of about 240,000 jobs added in Jan 2016, with a standard deviation of 135,000 - leading to forecasts of (<175) 30%
(<225) 15%
(>225) 55% I note that the middle bin is quite small (50,000 jobs) given the error variation from month to month. I am surprised that the crowd is assigning such a high probability to it, which probably needs further digging to understand. I then modified my forecast as follows - 1. The high forecast is partly explained by the high jobs added in Nov/Dec 2015 (252,000 and 292,000 respectively). These are preliminary numbers, and could be revised down.
2. Typical standard deviation (in "normal times" i.e. excluding recession periods) is around 60,000 - 80,000 rather than the 135,000 that a simple regression analysis gives. I therefore lowered my estimate for average jobs added in the Oct-Dec 2015 period to 230,000 per month (giving a Jan 2016 forecast of 220,000)  and lowered the standard deviation of the forecast to 80,000 which leads to (<175) 30%
(<225) 25%
(>225) 45% i.e. a bit more weight added into the middle bucket, and some removed from the top bucket. This continues to reflect by belief that the middle bucket is unusually small given the typical variation in jobs added, whilst being a bit closer to the crowd's forecast.

I have decided to simply average the last 3, 6, and then 12 months to come up with a figure. I then assigned a weighted average of 45%, 35% and 25% to each of those figures. I am aware there are many other ways to approach this question including by factoring in how much January generally diverges from other months. As the reliability of the single month figures has been more vocally questioned over the past few years (citation needed, I know,  but no data other than my own impression to validate this claim) this may be a worthwhile consideration. Even so, I see this as unhelpful complexity with little/no data to establish proven predictive value. I think the same thing of other, additional considerations I have seen used. The end result was 263k per month. I will update my figures based on “consensus” estimates (probably Bloomberg’s survey) as the date approaches, but I put little stock in these either.

Not sure if anyone has added this but I will here for those who REALLY like diving into the question(s). The BLS uses a payroll "reference period" to estimate its initial jobs number. That reference period INCLUDES the 12th of the month.   In other words, in their survey of business and govt entities they want to know how many workers were added or subtracted (subtractions are more complicated to calculate) during the pay period that includes the 12th of a given month. So, if we are looking of any clues the 12th is next Tuesday so we are in the midst of looking holistically at what business/govt might be doing right now.   Is retail shedding part-time holiday workers this week?  Has the beefed up part-time hiring (ancillary businesses, not just ones directly affected) for Star Wars stopped and reversing.  It the weather turning sour and construction slowing down, on a seasonal basis?  We know from another question that oil prices are hitting the oil patch severely--will the job losses continue there as well?   On a positive note, new housing starts were up considerably in November (latest report came out on Dec 12, I think). Will construction continue to defy expectations? The Atlanta Fed publishes a respected GDP report virtually in live-time.  They are reporting 4th quarter GDP at less than 1%.  How can we have robust job growth AND very low GDP growth---at the same time. Is productivity THAT bad?  Or is there a disconnect somewhere?  If anyone has any ideas on that I would love to hear them!  Anyway---the reference period for January is upon us, so the clues are out there right now for us to reveal!   :)

Looking at BLS monthly stats 1939-2015 http://data.bls.gov/pdq/SurveyOutputServlet (Thanks, GeneH), I couldn't eyeball any clear pattern, either within years or across years. Looking at the issue another way, I thought that past performance of the job creation market is unlikely to have a strong influence on a current month's job creation beyond a certain period.  On gut instinct, I picked 6 months as that likely period. Exporting the 1939-2015 data to a spreadsheet, I deleted Feb-Jun for each year and shifted the January column to follow the previous year's Jul-Dec.   It seems to me that what's characteristic of Jan 2016 is that it is following a period of sustained, uninterrupted (albeit variable) growth in job creation.  For that reason, I deleted all years (rows) in which there had been even a single month of negative job growth in the 6 mos. preceding January.  This left years '42, '51, '55, '61, '65-'68, '71, '73, '75-'79, '84-'89, '92-'96, '98, '99, '04-'06, and '11-'14.  I call these "sustained growth years" below. A sensible "baseline" for each January seemed (again, gut instinct) to be the three months preceding January, so for each of these years, I averaged job figures for Oct-Dec.  I then compared each Jan job figure with the average of the preceding Oct-Dec to calculate the fraction/multiple of the "baseline" the Jan job figure represented. I then calculated the Oct-Dec 2015 "baseline" (= avg. 283,400 jobs/mo.) To get a sense for what Jan performance for each of the sustained growth years would have looked like for each of the sustained growth years identified above, I multiplied the Oct-Dec 2015 baseline figure by the Jan fraction/multiple figure for each sustained growth year.  This yielded a set of 35 corresponding values, which I separated into the <175K, 175K-225K, and >225K categories recited in the question.  Final tally: <175K, 15 of 35 values = 42.9% 
175K-225K, 2 of 35 values = 5.7%
>225K, 18 of 35 values = 51.4% To do:  Look at these sustained growth years some more to see if I can figure out any reason why Jan #s were up or down relative to preceding Oct-Dec and try to correlate with the same reason as of Oct-Dec 2015. Thought:  This might correlate with Employers' anticipation of worker need.  What is that anticipation called?  Who measures it?  Where is it recorded?  (Does anyone know?)

The last time more than 225,000 jobs were added (in the month of January) was 2007.  Mostly, fewer jobs are created in January after the holiday season--but certainly not always.  Since 2005 (and January of 2006), more jobs have been created three times in the January (from December of the year prior).  Additionally, only three times has that number been more than 225,000 jobs.  Since January of 2006, the number the jobs created mark has fallen below 175,000 has been six times, however, four of those, I would argue, were during the recession years (but once in January of 2014).  But on the year, job growth is slowing slightly and with the Chinese stock market tanking, I can't imagine this won't have some affect on numbers going forward.  So I believe looking at the past rates and the recent events that could affect this projection, it's safe to be between 175 and 225k for now.

- It’s hard to see much of a connection between job growth in December of one year and job growth in the following January over the last 10 years.
- 6 times the December numbers have been better, and 4 times they’ve been lower. But the average ((median + mean/2) over the same period of the absolute value of the difference between December and January is 26. That looks like it’s a good predicator, but the standard deviation is over 140!
- In fact there seems to be a a slightly looser connection between job growth in November of one year and job growth in the following January over the last 10 years. The average ((median + mean/2) over the same period of the absolute value of the difference between December and January is 33. Here the standard deviation is also pretty big, though smaller than that for December: 124.
- So I think that the December numbers predict about a modest (2%) increase in likelihood.

This has happened in the past when these indicators are at odds. The initial jobs numbers come from a survey at a particular time of the month--a "stock". Regressions seem to indicate extremely low correlation between Jobs and either to US stock market or Composite PMI index or with job gains either a month before, a quarter before or a year before.  In terms of averages, the average job gains in January (according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics) over the past 4 years has been about 230,000-240,000. 
This isn't what other outlets seem to be reporting - seems a little high. Using alternative measures, the average for January over the past 4 years sinks to 192,500 in January.  Using jobs reports from the media, average number of jobs gained in December is roughly 155,000 and from past trends, it appears that there tend to be more jobs created in January than in December.  Coming off a year with very strong job growth and low wage increases as well as a "healthy" holiday shopping season ( https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/business/wp/2015/12/28/retailers-ring-up-healthy-sales-this-holiday-season/ ), I would expect trends from previous years to continue (i.e. job growth in January will be somewhere in the ballpark of 190,000 and exceed jobs gained in December) unless:
1. There are sharp increases in commodity prices (not very likely given what's happening in China, Saudi Arabia and Russia) 
2. There is a contraction in the United States economy (also not particularly likely - GDP growth for 2015 may not be stellar in the United States, but it was healthy enough, all things considered)
3. Inflation or wage growth suddenly skyrocket (wage increases are likely, but probably not too extreme and I don't think inflation in December or January will be an issue) All that being said, a big piece of data that will significantly clarify things will be the December jobs report.

This initial forecast will be meaningfully informed by this Friday's NFP. The trend lays in the 175-225 field so I'm putting confidence there to begin with. Mild weather and decent sales data suggests the topside should, for now, outweigh downside risk. We'll see what Friday offers,meow ever.
